elements.content: Two new mixed ligand coordination polymers (CPs) that are sulfonic group functionalized, namely, {[Cd­(bpe)0.5(5-sip)­(H2O)]·4H2O­(bpeH2)0.5} n (1) and {[Cd1.5(bte)­(5-sip)­(H2O)3]·3H2O} n (2) [where 5-sip = trinegative 5-sulfoisophthalate salt, bpe = 4,4′-bispyridylethane, bte = 1,2-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­ethane] have been synthesized through the variation of the N,N′-donor connectors only, at room temperature by using a slow diffusion technique. The structural analyses of both the complexes by single crystal X-ray diffraction studies clearly revealed the formation of 2D sheets containing guest water molecules entrapped in the 1D channel. A structurally similar reported compound {[Cd1.5(btp)­(5-sip)­(H2O)3]·2H2O} n (3) has also been synthesized to compare the property of the newly synthesized compound. Herein, all the compounds show their humidity dependent proton conductivity as well as gas sorption behavior, which are signatures of their multifunctionality in the field of not only synthetic chemistry but also in material science. It is worth mentioning that the hydrogen bond network by the guest/coordinated waters, dicarboxylic, as well as sulfonic acid group(s) are present in the interlayer spaces, which are basically responsible for showing this high degree of proton conductivity in addition to significant water adsorption. Interesting phase transformation of compound 1 during experimental study perhaps plays a crucial role for its highest conductivity value among the three reported compounds. Herein it has found that the proton conductivity values vary in the range of ∼10–5–10–7 S cm–1 at 65 °C under 95% relative humidity (RH) corroborating the Grotthus mechanism of proton conduction. All the dehydrated frameworks exhibit adsorption of different gases (e.g., CO2 and N2) and solvents (e.g., EtOH and H2O). In the case of compound 1 and 3, selective CO2 uptake has been observed.

elements.content: Proton conductivity and different sorption study for three sulfonic group functionalized mixed ligand coordination polymers have been performed. One compound shows interesting structural dynamicity which clearly correlates with the highest proton conductivity as well as highest carbon dioxide sorption for that compound compared to the others.

elements.content: Modern civilization has a great thirst to find alternative energy sources which can act as an effectual substitute of fossil fuel. In this context, the fuel cell technology may be a suitable answer to combat the detrimental use of fossil fuel burned energy causing life threatening environmental disorder. Hence, proton (ion) conduction has become a very decisive phenomenon in this respect, and the contemporary researchers are quite engrossed to design the effective frameworks exhibiting this important aspect due to their potential applications in transport dynamics, electrochemical devices, and of course fuel cells. Besides, due to high throughput anthropogenic emission of flue gases during the burning of fossil fuels causing global warming to a large extent, it is therefore highly required to design some effective CO2 adsorbing materials to decrease the level of CO2 emitted from industrial flue gases. To explore the materials with enhanced proton conductivity as well as gas uptake capacity, herein we have preferred the coordination polymers (CPs) due to their obvious advantages of having tunable pore size, shape, volume, surface area, along with the preferred fabrication of their chemical pore environment through structural modulation of organic linkers in terms of their size, shape, and functional group(s). The design and synthesis of such materials is also very important to contemporary researchers because of the formation of its diverse topological architecture and enormous applications, such as selective gas storage and separation, electrical and proton conduction, ion exchange, photoluminescence, magnetism, so on and so forth. Each individual property such as sorption, proton conductivity by various CPs as well as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely explored but, interestingly, the frameworks that exhibit two different properties simultaneously to a significant extent are not reported and are not common. Thus, we have taken a suitable strategy to design and fabricate the CPs/MOFs to achieve their multifunctionality in this realm. Here we have utilized the sulfonic acid (−SO3H) or sulfonate (−SO3 –) group functionalized mixed ligand CPs, which exhibit their multifunctional behavior, i.e., proton conduction and gas storage properties. The compounds contain coordinated as well as lattice water molecules along with sulfonate (−SO3 –) group functionalized pore walls in the supramolecular 3D framework. Compound 1 contains uncoordinated protonated bpe (i.e., bpeH2) ligands in the pore, resulting in the formation of extensive hydrophilic channel through the intermolecular H-bonding networks suitable for proton conductive media. The proton conduction pathway through the intermolecular hydrogen bonding networks among the guest molecules, e.g., lattice waters and/or bpe ligands and the coordinated waters/–SO3 –/–CO2 – groups, which raveled the Grotthuss mechanism supported proton conduction for all cases. According to the basic logic of humidity dependent proton conductivity, the conductivity value might increase with the increasing of % RH, which favors the inclusion of more water molecules into the framework cavity. This framework trapped water perhaps play as a superior proton conductive media as it can easily release its protons to the adjacent layers of different acid groups (sulfonate/carboxylate) present in the systems with the help of long-range intermolecular H-bonding. On the other hand, different N-donor ligands present in the frameworks are playing roles in different gas sorption due to their flexibility and different polarity. Herein, the N,N′-donor ligands used, namely, bpe (for 1), bte (for 2), and btp (for 3), have their structural dynamic character by itself due to containing a flexible saturated aliphatic chain. Hence it is expected to get their structural dynamicity in the synthesized compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Modern civilization has a great thirst to find alternative energy sources which can act as an effectual substitute of fossil fuel. In this context, the fuel cell technology may be a suitable answer to combat the detrimental use of fossil fuel burned energy causing life threatening environmental disorder. Hence, proton (ion) conduction has become a very decisive phenomenon in this respect, and the contemporary researchers are quite engrossed to design the effective frameworks exhibiting this important aspect due to their potential applications in transport dynamics, electrochemical devices, and of course fuel cells. Besides, due to high throughput anthropogenic emission of flue gases during the burning of fossil fuels causing global warming to a large extent, it is therefore highly required to design some effective CO2 adsorbing materials to decrease the level of CO2 emitted from industrial flue gases. To explore the materials with enhanced proton conductivity as well as gas uptake capacity, herein we have preferred the coordination polymers (CPs) due to their obvious advantages of having tunable pore size, shape, volume, surface area, along with the preferred fabrication of their chemical pore environment through structural modulation of organic linkers in terms of their size, shape, and functional group(s). The design and synthesis of such materials is also very important to contemporary researchers because of the formation of its diverse topological architecture and enormous applications, such as selective gas storage and separation, electrical and proton conduction, ion exchange, photoluminescence, magnetism, so on and so forth. Each individual property such as sorption, proton conductivity by various CPs as well as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely explored but, interestingly, the frameworks that exhibit two different properties simultaneously to a significant extent are not reported and are not common. Thus, we have taken a suitable strategy to design and fabricate the CPs/MOFs to achieve their multifunctionality in this realm. Here we have utilized the sulfonic acid (-SO3H) or sulfonate (-SO3 -) group functionalized mixed ligand CPs, which exhibit their multifunctional behavior, i.e., proton conduction and gas storage properties. The compounds contain coordinated as well as lattice water molecules along with sulfonate (-SO3 -) group functionalized pore walls in the supramolecular 3D framework. Compound 1 contains uncoordinated protonated bpe (i.e., bpeH2) ligands in the pore, resulting in the formation of extensive hydrophilic channel through the intermolecular H-bonding networks suitable for proton conductive media. The proton conduction pathway through the intermolecular hydrogen bonding networks among the guest molecules, e.g., lattice waters and/or bpe ligands and the coordinated waters/-SO3 -/-CO2 - groups, which raveled the Grotthuss mechanism supported proton conduction for all cases. According to the basic logic of humidity dependent proton conductivity, the conductivity value might increase with the increasing of % RH, which favors the inclusion of more water molecules into the framework cavity. This framework trapped water perhaps play as a superior proton conductive media as it can easily release its protons to the adjacent layers of different acid groups (sulfonate/carboxylate) present in the systems with the help of long-range intermolecular H-bonding. On the other hand, different N-donor ligands present in the frameworks are playing roles in different gas sorption due to their flexibility and different polarity. Herein, the N,N'-donor ligands used, namely, bpe (for 1), bte (for 2), and btp (for 3), have their structural dynamic character by itself due to containing a flexible saturated aliphatic chain. Hence it is expected to get their structural dynamicity in the synthesized compounds.

elements.content: As a continuation of our previous work, here we have presented two more 5-sulfoisophthalate based mixed ligand CPs, namely, {[Cd­(bpe)0.5(5-sip)­(H2O)]·4H2O (bpeH2)0.5} n (1), {[Cd1.5(bte)­(5-sip)­(H2O)3]·3H2O} n (2) and synthesized a previously reported compound {[Cd1.5(btp)­(5-sip)­(H2O)3]·2H2O} n (3) following a different synthetic route. All the frameworks exhibit interesting temperature and relative humidity (% RH) dependent proton conductivity. There are many ways to enhance the proton conductivity in 2D frameworks under humid conditions, but we have focused mainly on enhanced proton conductivity due to a solid state phase transition. Particularly, in the case of compound 1, phase transition starts at ∼50 °C and it forms a new phase at the impedance temperature (i.e., at 65 °C), whereas no phase transformations have been observed for the remaining two compounds at 65 °C. So, here the structural flexibility of compound 1 can be expected to exhibit a better conductivity value than the other two compounds. All the compounds exhibit maximum proton conductivities at 95% RH, and among them 1 exhibits the highest value. The maximum conductivity of the compounds 1–3 vary to a wide range lying in (4.6 × 10–7)–(3.7 × 10–5) at 95% RH and 65 °C, and their activation energy (E a) is from 0.30 to 0.48, clearly indicating the Grotthuss mechanism of proton conductivity. All the CPs show sorption behavior for gas (e.g., CO2, N2) and solvent (e.g., H2O, EtOH), where the CO2 adsorption is selective for the compounds 1 and 3. Hence, these frameworks can serve two environmentally friendly purposes, and such multifunctional nature makes broad future aspects for these types of materials.

elements.content: The reagents for the synthesis of CPs 1–3 (see ), e.g., cadmium­(II) nitrate hexahydrate, the acid monosodium-5-sulfoisophtalic acid (5-NaH2SIP), and one of the ligands 4,4′-bispyridylethane (bpe) were procured from Merck Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. Inc. The monosodium acid salt was neutralized with Na2CO3 (1:1) in aqueous medium for the preparation of its trisodium salt (Na3SIP). The other two N,N′-donor lignads, i.e., 1,2-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­ethane (bte), 1,3-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­propane (btp), were synthesized by following the literature procedure.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals

The reagents for the synthesis of CPs 1-3 (see ), e.g., cadmium(II) nitrate hexahydrate, the acid monosodium-5-sulfoisophtalic acid (5-NaH2SIP), and one of the ligands 4,4'-bispyridylethane (bpe) were procured from Merck Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. Inc. The monosodium acid salt was neutralized with Na2CO3 (1:1) in aqueous medium for the preparation of its trisodium salt (Na3SIP). The other two N,N'-donor lignads, i.e., 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)ethane (bte), 1,3-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propane (btp), were synthesized by following the literature procedure.

elements.content: Using Heraeus CHNS analyzer elemental analyses (C, H, and N) of the compounds were performed. FT-IR spectra (4000–400 cm–1) were recorded on KBr pellets of the samples using a PerkinElmer Spectrum BX-II IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for the complexes 1–3 was carried out within the temperature range of 30–600 °C using a PerkinElmer Simultaneous Thermal Analyzer (STA 8000). During thermal analysis, the flow rate of nitrogen 10 cm3/min and the furnace heating rate of 3 °C/min were maintained. The bulk purity of the compounds 1–3 and their postimpedance framework stability were confirmed by a powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) study. The PXRD measurement was performed on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Using Heraeus CHNS analyzer elemental analyses (C, H, and N) of the compounds were performed. FT-IR spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were recorded on KBr pellets of the samples using a PerkinElmer Spectrum BX-II IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for the complexes 1-3 was carried out within the temperature range of 30-600 °C using a PerkinElmer Simultaneous Thermal Analyzer (STA 8000). During thermal analysis, the flow rate of nitrogen 10 cm3/min and the furnace heating rate of 3 °C/min were maintained. The bulk purity of the compounds 1-3 and their postimpedance framework stability were confirmed by a powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) study. The PXRD measurement was performed on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer at room temperature.

elements.content: The sorption study has been performed on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ adsorption instrument using highly pure N2 gas (99.999% purity) and CO2 (99.95% purity) gas. The N2 gas adsorption at 77 K (maintained by using liquid-nitrogen bath) and CO2 adsorption at 195 K (temperature maintained by dry ice-acetone cold bath) were carried out for the dehydrated frameworks of 1–3 in the pressure range of 0–1 bar; taking the corresponding samples in the hard glass sample tube. Before performing the isotherm measurements, the as-synthesized compounds of 1–3 (∼50 mg each) were activated at 423 K, for 4 h under a vacuum of 1 × 10–1 Pa. After activation, helium gas (99.999% purity) was diffused into the sample tube at a certain pressure by controlling the automatic valves of the instrument. The difference of pressure (P cal – P e) signifies the gas adsorption volume, where P e indicates the observed pressure at equilibrium and P cal denotes the calculated pressure with no gas adsorption. On the other hand, H2O and dry EtOH vapor sorption isotherms were performed for the dehydrated compounds of 1–3 (∼45 mg for each) at 298 K and the pressure ranging from 0 to 24 Torr and 0 to 46 Torr, respectively, for H2O and EtOH using the same instrument. The vapor was generated by heating the corresponding solvent molecules. For both of the cases in solvent vapor sorption measurement, helium gas was also used in the same manner to measure the dead volume as mentioned earlier. The pressure change was monitored by taking the adsorbent in the sample tube, and the degree of adsorption was calculated by observing the decrease in pressure at equilibrium, similar to the procedure applied in case of gas adsorption.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Measurements

The sorption study has been performed on a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ adsorption instrument using highly pure N2 gas (99.999% purity) and CO2 (99.95% purity) gas. The N2 gas adsorption at 77 K (maintained by using liquid-nitrogen bath) and CO2 adsorption at 195 K (temperature maintained by dry ice-acetone cold bath) were carried out for the dehydrated frameworks of 1-3 in the pressure range of 0-1 bar; taking the corresponding samples in the hard glass sample tube. Before performing the isotherm measurements, the as-synthesized compounds of 1-3 (~50 mg each) were activated at 423 K, for 4 h under a vacuum of 1 × 10-1 Pa. After activation, helium gas (99.999% purity) was diffused into the sample tube at a certain pressure by controlling the automatic valves of the instrument. The difference of pressure (P cal - P e) signifies the gas adsorption volume, where P e indicates the observed pressure at equilibrium and P cal denotes the calculated pressure with no gas adsorption. On the other hand, H2O and dry EtOH vapor sorption isotherms were performed for the dehydrated compounds of 1-3 (~45 mg for each) at 298 K and the pressure ranging from 0 to 24 Torr and 0 to 46 Torr, respectively, for H2O and EtOH using the same instrument. The vapor was generated by heating the corresponding solvent molecules. For both of the cases in solvent vapor sorption measurement, helium gas was also used in the same manner to measure the dead volume as mentioned earlier. The pressure change was monitored by taking the adsorbent in the sample tube, and the degree of adsorption was calculated by observing the decrease in pressure at equilibrium, similar to the procedure applied in case of gas adsorption.

elements.content: Impedance measurements were carried out for compounds 1–3 using the Solartron SI 1260 Impedance/Gain-Phase Analyzer and 1296 Dielectric Interface, where the frequency varies from 0.1 to 1 × 106 Hz. For the execution of the experiment, an Espec Corp. SH-221incubator was also utilized for controlling both the temperature and the relative humidity (% RH). For the measurements, settings of each of the conditions in Espec Corp. SH-221 incubator were done for approximately 12 h. For each sample, a compacted pellet of diameter 2.5 mm and thickness of 1.40 mm, 1.98 mm, and 2.27 mm for 1–3, respectively, were made ready by pressing the powder samples at ∼400 MPa for 60 s. Then the corresponding proton conductivities of compounds 1–3 were measured using two gold wires (50 μm diameter) connected by gold paste in the pellets with the trivial two probe technique. The determination of resistance values were done from equivalent circuit fits of the first semicircle using Z-View software.
elements.clean_text:
Proton Conduction Measurement

Impedance measurements were carried out for compounds 1-3 using the Solartron SI 1260 Impedance/Gain-Phase Analyzer and 1296 Dielectric Interface, where the frequency varies from 0.1 to 1 × 106 Hz. For the execution of the experiment, an Espec Corp. SH-221incubator was also utilized for controlling both the temperature and the relative humidity (% RH). For the measurements, settings of each of the conditions in Espec Corp. SH-221 incubator were done for approximately 12 h. For each sample, a compacted pellet of diameter 2.5 mm and thickness of 1.40 mm, 1.98 mm, and 2.27 mm for 1-3, respectively, were made ready by pressing the powder samples at ~400 MPa for 60 s. Then the corresponding proton conductivities of compounds 1-3 were measured using two gold wires (50 μm diameter) connected by gold paste in the pellets with the trivial two probe technique. The determination of resistance values were done from equivalent circuit fits of the first semicircle using Z-View software.

elements.content: The X-ray single-crystal data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected at room temperature in a Bruker made APEX II diffractometer. At first, single crystals of both the compounds were isolated and then mounted on the glass fiber tip using commercial super glue. For the data collection, graphite monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) from a sealed tube X-ray source has been used. The raw data were integrated using the SAINT program and by utilizing SADABS, the absorption corrections were performed. The structures were solved by SIR-92, and full-matrix least-squares refinements on F2 for all non-hydrogen atoms were performed by SHELXL-2016/4, with anisotropic displacement parameters. For complex 1, the pyridyl N atom of lattice bpe ligand is highly thermally disordered; it was split into two fragments (i.e., N2A and N2B) with 0.5 occupancy for each. The hydrogen atoms were located geometrically at their proper positions and fixed using the HFIX command for all cases except for the thermally disordered N2, C15, and C19 atoms. All the calculations and molecular graphics were done by SHELXL-2016, PLATON v1.15, WinGX system Ver-1.80, Diamond, Mercury, and TOPOS. All the crystallographic data and structural refinement parameters for the compounds 1 and 2 have been mentioned in . CCDC 1936073 and 1936074 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement

The X-ray single-crystal data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected at room temperature in a Bruker made APEX II diffractometer. At first, single crystals of both the compounds were isolated and then mounted on the glass fiber tip using commercial super glue. For the data collection, graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) from a sealed tube X-ray source has been used. The raw data were integrated using the SAINT program and by utilizing SADABS, the absorption corrections were performed. The structures were solved by SIR-92, and full-matrix least-squares refinements on F2 for all non-hydrogen atoms were performed by SHELXL-2016/4, with anisotropic displacement parameters. For complex 1, the pyridyl N atom of lattice bpe ligand is highly thermally disordered; it was split into two fragments (i.e., N2A and N2B) with 0.5 occupancy for each. The hydrogen atoms were located geometrically at their proper positions and fixed using the HFIX command for all cases except for the thermally disordered N2, C15, and C19 atoms. All the calculations and molecular graphics were done by SHELXL-2016, PLATON v1.15, WinGX system Ver-1.80, Diamond, Mercury, and TOPOS. All the crystallographic data and structural refinement parameters for the compounds 1 and 2 have been mentioned in . CCDC 1936073 and 1936074 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

The aqueous solution (20 mL) of trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (Na3SIP) (1 mmol, 0.312 g) and the methanolic solution (20 mL) of 4,4′-bispyridylethane (bpe) (1 mmol, 0.184 g) were mixed and stirred for 1 h to make the homogeneous mixture. In an another beaker, Cd­(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 0.308 g) was dissolved in 20 mL of water. Then, in a glass tube, 6 mL of above-mentioned mixed-ligand solution was slowly and carefully layered on 3 mL of the Cd­(II) solution. A volume of 5 mL of buffer solution (1:1 of H2O and MeOH) was used between the two above-mentioned solutions to perform a slow reaction. Then after sealing the mouth of the tube, it was kept at room temperature uninterruptedly. White block shaped single crystals were obtained after 14 days, and they were quite suitable for further characterization. The crystals were washed with a 1:1 methanol–water mixture after separation and dried under air (yield 75% based on metal salt used). Anal. Calcd for C20H26N2O12SCd (%): C, 38.08; H, 4.15; N, 4.44. Found: C, 38.12; H, 4.11; N, 4.41. IR spectra (in cm–1): ν­(CC), 1613–1433; ν­(SO), 1116(s); ν­(C–O), 1207; ν­(O–H, H2O), 3466; and ν­(C–H, Ar), 3062.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

{[Cd(bpe)0.5(5-sip)(H2O)]⋅4H2O(bpeH2)0.5} n  (1)

The aqueous solution (20 mL) of trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (Na3SIP) (1 mmol, 0.312 g) and the methanolic solution (20 mL) of 4,4'-bispyridylethane (bpe) (1 mmol, 0.184 g) were mixed and stirred for 1 h to make the homogeneous mixture. In an another beaker, Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1 mmol, 0.308 g) was dissolved in 20 mL of water. Then, in a glass tube, 6 mL of above-mentioned mixed-ligand solution was slowly and carefully layered on 3 mL of the Cd(II) solution. A volume of 5 mL of buffer solution (1:1 of H2O and MeOH) was used between the two above-mentioned solutions to perform a slow reaction. Then after sealing the mouth of the tube, it was kept at room temperature uninterruptedly. White block shaped single crystals were obtained after 14 days, and they were quite suitable for further characterization. The crystals were washed with a 1:1 methanol-water mixture after separation and dried under air (yield 75% based on metal salt used). Anal. Calcd for C20H26N2O12SCd (%): C, 38.08; H, 4.15; N, 4.44. Found: C, 38.12; H, 4.11; N, 4.41. IR spectra (in cm-1): ν(CC), 1613-1433; ν(SO), 1116(s); ν(C-O), 1207; ν(O-H, H2O), 3466; and ν(C-H, Ar), 3062.

elements.content: Compound 2 was synthesized following the same procedure of 1 with the use of 1,2-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­ethane (bte) (1 mmol, 0.164 g) in place of 4,4′-bispyridylethane (bpe) (1 mmol, 0.184 g). White block shaped single crystals which are appropriate for structural characterization were obtained after 15 days. The crystals were washed with a 1:1 methanol–water mixture after separation (yield 50%). Anal. Calcd for C28H46N12O26S2Cd3(%): C, 24.58; H, 3.39; N, 12.29. Found: C, 24.61; H, 3.35; N, 12.32. elements.content: It is revealed by the single-crystal structure analysis that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. A 2D sheet is formed by the connection of both the trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (5-sip3–) and 4,4′-bispyridylethane (bpe) ligands to the metal center. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Cd­(II) ion, one 4,4′-bispyridylethane (bpe) ligand (where, half unit is coordinated and the other half unit is protonated and uncoordinated), one trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (5-sip3–), one coordinated and four lattice water molecules. Cd­(II) centers possess distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry being hepta-coordinated where CdO6N is the coordination environment (a) around the metal center. This CdO6N environment is composed of one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N1) and six oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3, O4, O5, and O1W) of three trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (5-sip3–) and one coordinated water molecule, respectively. The Cd–O bond lengths vary from 2.241(2) to 2.716(2) Å; and the Cd–N bond length is 2.263(3) Å (Table S1). Here, each 5-sip3–bridges with three Cd­(II) centers in monodentate and bis-chelating fashion to form a 1D ladder along the crystallographic a-axis (b). These metal-carboxylate 1D ladders are pillared by the N,N′-donor 4,4′-bispyridylethane (bpe) ligand to form a 2D sheet (c). Finally, the 2D sheets form a supramolecular 3D structure by the intermolecular H-bonding with the coordinated and guest water molecules (Figure S4). The TOPOS analysis of compound 1 indicates a 3,4-c binodal net with stoichiometry (3-c)­(4-c) and Schläfli symbol {42.63.8}­{42.6} (d).

Structural Description

A 2D sheet is formed by the connection of both the trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (5-sip3-) and 4,4'-bispyridylethane (bpe) ligands to the metal center. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one Cd(II) ion, one 4,4'-bispyridylethane (bpe) ligand (where, half unit is coordinated and the other half unit is protonated and uncoordinated), one trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (5-sip3-), one coordinated and four lattice water molecules. Cd(II) centers possess distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry being hepta-coordinated where CdO6N is the coordination environment (a) around the metal center. This CdO6N environment is composed of one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N1) and six oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3, O4, O5, and O1W) of three trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (5-sip3-) and one coordinated water molecule, respectively. The Cd-O bond lengths vary from 2.241(2) to 2.716(2) Å; and the Cd-N bond length is 2.263(3) Å (Table S1). Here, each 5-sip3-bridges with three Cd(II) centers in monodentate and bis-chelating fashion to form a 1D ladder along the crystallographic a-axis (b). These metal-carboxylate 1D ladders are pillared by the N,N'-donor 4,4'-bispyridylethane (bpe) ligand to form a 2D sheet (c). Finally, the 2D sheets form a supramolecular 3D structure by the intermolecular H-bonding with the coordinated and guest water molecules (Figure S4). elements.content: From the single-crystal structural analysis, it is confirmed that compound 2 is crystallized in the triclinic P1̅ space group and also exhibits a 2D sheet structure through the bridging/pillaring of trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (5-sip3–) and 1,2-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­ethane (bte) ligands. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains two crystallographically independent Cd­(II) ions with one unit of Cd1 and half unit of Cd2 center, one 1,2-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­ethane (bte) ligand, one trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (5-sip3–), three coordinated and three lattice water molecules. The hepta-coordinated Cd1 center exhibits a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with a CdO6N coordination environment (a), which is composed of one pyridyl nitrogen atom (N1) of 1,2-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­ethane (bte) ligand and six oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3 a , O4 a , O1W, and O2W) of two trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (5-sip3–) and two coordinated water molecules, respectively. On the other hand, the hexa-coordinated Cd2 center has a distorted octahedral geometry with a CdO4N2 coordination environment originated by two symmetry related pyridyl nitrogen atoms (i.e., N6 and N6 b ) of two different 1,2-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­ethane (bte) ligands and two pair of symmetry related oxygen atoms (i.e., O7 c /O7 d and O3W/O3W b ) from two trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (5-sip3–) and two coordinated water molecules, respectively (a). The Cd–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.266(3) to 2.677(4) Å (for Cd1) and 2.276(5) to 2.248(4) Å (for Cd2), whereas Cd–N bond length is 2.300(4) Å for Cd1 and 2.289(4) for Cd2 centers (Table S3). Here, each 5-sip3– connects three adjacent Cd­(II) centers, where two Cd1 centers are connected with the bis-chelated mode of two −COO– groups and one Cd2 center with monodentate bridging mode of −SO3 – resulting in the formation of a 1D ladder along crystallographic b-axis (b). These 1D metal-carboxylate ladders by both the Cd1 and Cd2 metal centers are pillared by the N,N′-donor 1,2-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­ethane (bte) ligands to form a 2D sheet (c). Finally, the 2D sheets form a supramolecular 3D structure by intermolecular H-bonding with the guest as well as coordinated water molecules (Figure S5). The TOPOS analysis of compound 2 indicates a 3,4-c binodal net with stoichiometry (3-c)­4­(4-c) and Schläfli symbol {62.84}­{62.8}­4 (d).

elements.content: In spite of following a different synthetic procedure, the single-crystal data reveals that compound 3 has the same structure with the compound reported earlier by Tian et al. In this structure, each 5-sip3– bridges with three adjacent Cd1 centers, in a bis-chelated oxo-bridging fashion, from two −COO– groups resulting in the formation of a 1D ladder (a). After that, the N,N′-donor 1,3-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­propane (btp) ligands act as a pillar between the Cd1-carboxylate 1D ladders and Cd2 centers infinitely, resulting in the formation of a 2D sheet (b). Finally, the 2D sheet exhibits a supramolecular 3D structure by means of intermolecular H-bonding with the guest as well as coordinated water molecules (Figure S6). The TOPOS analysis of compound 3 exhibits a 3,4-c binodal net with stoichiometry (3-c)­(4-c) and Schläfli symbol {42.63.8}­{42.6}­(c).

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was performed using the as-synthesized powder samples of compounds 1–3 (Figures S7–S9) at room temperature. The experimental peak positions of compounds 1 and 2 were in well agreement with the simulated pattern, whereas the peak position of compound 3 is also quite similar to the reported data. The above facts suggesting the phase purity of all the synthesized compounds. In addition, the PXRD analysis of post impedance samples (see proton conductivity section) of compounds 1–3 have also been carried out at room temperature, where in the case of 2 and 3, the PXRD patterns matched well with their respective simulated patterns suggesting their framework rigidity after conductivity measurements (Figures S8 and S9). For the postimpedance sample of 1, most of the peaks are quite similar to its as-synthesized PXRD pattern, but there is the emergence of some new peaks at 2θ ∼ 10–25°, possibly due to the dynamic nature of the frameworks (Figure S7).
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) Analysis and Discussion of Structural Flexibility

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis was performed using the as-synthesized powder samples of compounds 1-3 (Figures S7-S9) at room temperature. The experimental peak positions of compounds 1 and 2 were in well agreement with the simulated pattern, whereas the peak position of compound 3 is also quite similar to the reported data. The above facts suggesting the phase purity of all the synthesized compounds. In addition, the PXRD analysis of post impedance samples (see proton conductivity section) of compounds 1-3 have also been carried out at room temperature, where in the case of 2 and 3, the PXRD patterns matched well with their respective simulated patterns suggesting their framework rigidity after conductivity measurements (Figures S8 and S9). For the postimpedance sample of 1, most of the peaks are quite similar to its as-synthesized PXRD pattern, but there is the emergence of some new peaks at 2θ ~ 10-25°, possibly due to the dynamic nature of the frameworks (Figure S7).

elements.content: To understand the dynamic nature of the framework for compound 1, variable temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VTPXRD) analysis (Figure S10) was performed. In Figure S10, it has been observed that compound 1 exhibited its structural dynamicity started at ∼50 °C and also at the temperature (65 °C) of impedance analysis, and new phases have been grown which are clearly different from the as-synthesized phase. Interestingly, after activation of compound 1 at both 50 and 65 °C, it immediately came back to its initial phase (i.e., as-synthesized phase) upon exposure to a humid atmosphere. Hence, the structural dynamicity is very much clear from the VTPXRD but the structure reverts back to its original phase instantly after keeping it a long time at the room temperature. To investigate the scenario of such a phase transformation, we have performed the reversibility in different humidity. Interestingly, we found that the relative humidity (RH) is the other key factor along with temperature in controlling the reversibility. Since 65 °C and 95% RH are the experimental condition to measure the proton conductivity (see proton conductivity section), the compound was separately activated at 65 °C and it was divided into two parts. One part was kept in a sealed desiccator containing steaming hot distilled water (100% RH), and the other part was kept at normal atmosphere having a RH of ∼60%. The PXRD of the first batch, where the compound was kept at ∼100% RH conditions, is exactly similar to the PXRD of the postimpedance sample of compound 1 (Figure S11). On the other hand, the PXRD of the second batch where compound was kept at ∼60% RH, showed exact matching of all the peak positions with the PXRD of the as-synthesized pattern (Figure S12). Therefore, it is fairly established that both the temperature and RH are responsible together to exhibit such structural dynamicity in 1.

elements.content: The structural dynamicity of compound 1 compared to other two can be explained with respect to their basic coordination chemistry standpoint, which also corroborates with its highest proton conductivity value among the compounds 1–3. On the basis of the aliphatic chain length of all the individual ligands, it may be expected for btp ligand (for 3) to show the highest structural flexibility compared to bte (for 2) and bpe (for 1) ligand. It may also result in the highest conductivity value for 3, but the proton conductivity order of the compounds follows the trend of 1 > 3 > 2. This anomalous order of conductivity can be easily explained if we consider the respective Cd···Cd bond distances along the different N,N′-donor ligands. It has been observed that the Cd···Cd distances along the respective N,N′-donor ligands are 13.671 (for 1), 6.788 (for 2), and 10.141 (for 3); where it is nearly same along the 5-sulfoisophthalate (e.g., 10.208 for 1, 10.288 for 2, and 10.335 for 3). It is quite obvious that when any flexible ligand bridged with two metal centers through its two N-donor ends in a longer distance, there is a greater possibility to show their structural flexibility in the complex than the other ligands which are very tightly bonded with the adjacent metal centers. Thus, from this basic structural coordination viewpoint, it is very clear that compound 1 might show greatest structural dynamicity than others, which was also substantiated from the VTPXRD analysis and of course conduction values of compound 1 mentioned above. To get a better insight of the transformed phase in 1, we have indexed the PXRD pattern of the transformed phase of the compound 1 using the TREOR program (Figure S13) and found there is some increment in the cell volume in the transformed phase.

elements.content: To show the stability of the frameworks with heating, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1–3 was performed in the temperature range of 30–600 °C at the heating rate of 10 °C min–1 (Figure S14). Compound 1 showed a weight loss of 14.34% at 127 °C (calcd 14.28%) due to the loss of one coordinated and four lattice water molecules (Figure S14) per asymmetric unit. The framework was stable up to 270 °C without obvious decomposition. Compound 2 showed a weight loss of 16.14% at 126 °C (calcd 15.78%) due to the loss of three coordinated and three lattice water molecules (Figure S14) per asymmetric unit. The framework was stable up to 309 °C without obvious decomposition. Finally, compound 3 lost a weight of 13.44% at 147 °C (calcd 13.23%) due to the removal of three coordinated and two lattice water molecules per asymmetric unit, and the dehydrated framework was steady up to 310 °C. With further heating, the dehydrated frameworks of 1–3 were disintegrated into unidentified products.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

To show the stability of the frameworks with heating, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1-3 was performed in the temperature range of 30-600 °C at the heating rate of 10 °C min-1 (Figure S14). Compound 1 showed a weight loss of 14.34% at 127 °C (calcd 14.28%) due to the loss of one coordinated and four lattice water molecules (Figure S14) per asymmetric unit. The framework was stable up to 270 °C without obvious decomposition. Compound 2 showed a weight loss of 16.14% at 126 °C (calcd 15.78%) due to the loss of three coordinated and three lattice water molecules (Figure S14) per asymmetric unit. The framework was stable up to 309 °C without obvious decomposition. Finally, compound 3 lost a weight of 13.44% at 147 °C (calcd 13.23%) due to the removal of three coordinated and two lattice water molecules per asymmetric unit, and the dehydrated framework was steady up to 310 °C. With further heating, the dehydrated frameworks of 1-3 were disintegrated into unidentified products.

elements.content: The relationship between the adsorbed amount of water and the relative humidity (% RH) is very relevant to this study because the proton conduction is highly dependent on the relative humidity factor. Therefore, the water vapor sorption isotherms for all the compounds have been studied at 298 K ( and Figure S15–S17). The water sorption phenomena for the compounds interestingly display three-step water uptake profiles and the maximum uptake at P/P o = ∼0.9 reaches up to 255, 198, and 266 cc/g for 1–3, respectively. The three-step water uptake was initiated at low humidity with a small uptake, and then two-step pore-filling uptake was observed at ∼9–27% RH. The pore-filling steps were observed at low RH, i.e., 9, 27 and 12% RH, respectively, for compounds 1–3, which indicates the hydrophilic nature of all the samples. It is quite certain from the large hysteresis between adsorption–desorption isotherms that a solvent-filled hydrophilic channel suitable for proton conduction is present in all three structures (). Obviously, the proton conductivity gradually increased according to increment of RH and reached to the maximum value at 95% RH (), which can be explained by the formation of intermolecular H-bonded networks at higher RH.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Studies

The relationship between the adsorbed amount of water and the relative humidity (% RH) is very relevant to this study because the proton conduction is highly dependent on the relative humidity factor. Therefore, the water vapor sorption isotherms for all the compounds have been studied at 298 K ( and Figure S15-S17). The water sorption phenomena for the compounds interestingly display three-step water uptake profiles and the maximum uptake at P/P o = ~0.9 reaches up to 255, 198, and 266 cc/g for 1-3, respectively. The three-step water uptake was initiated at low humidity with a small uptake, and then two-step pore-filling uptake was observed at ~9-27% RH. The pore-filling steps were observed at low RH, i.e., 9, 27 and 12% RH, respectively, for compounds 1-3, which indicates the hydrophilic nature of all the samples. It is quite certain from the large hysteresis between adsorption-desorption isotherms that a solvent-filled hydrophilic channel suitable for proton conduction is present in all three structures (). Obviously, the proton conductivity gradually increased according to increment of RH and reached to the maximum value at 95% RH (), which can be explained by the formation of intermolecular H-bonded networks at higher RH.

elements.content: Water sorption study for compounds 1–3 measured at 298 K; filled and empty symbols signify the adsorption and desorption isotherms, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 4  Water sorption study for compounds 1-3 measured at 298 K; filled and empty symbols signify the adsorption and desorption isotherms, respectively.

elements.content: Apart from that, the nitrogen and carbon dioxide gas adsorption and EtOH vapor sorption were also studied for all the compounds. Compounds 1 and 3 exhibited selective adsorption of CO2 over N2 ( and ) at 195 K, whereas compound 2 showed negligible sorption (surface) for CO2 and N2 (). The compound 1 displayed a type-III adsorption isotherm for N2 up to 15.3 cc/g at 1 bar pressure, while it showed a typical type-I adsorption isotherm for CO2 up to 71 cm3/g at 195 K and 1 bar pressure with an incomplete desorption brunch (). The compound 1 exhibited the larger uptake of CO2 compared to the other two compounds, which could be explained by its framework dynamicity. Their selective adsorption behavior can be explained on the basis of the kinetic diameters of the two gas molecules (i.e., CO2 and N2) as well as the polar adsorbate–adsorbent interaction in the framework. The kinetic diameter of CO2 (3.3 Å) is slightly smaller than that of N2 (3.6 Å), which helps the dehydrated framework of compound 1 to accommodate a greater amount of CO2 molecules into the void. Besides, the C atom of quadrupolar CO2 molecule is Lewis acidic in nature; thus, it has a high tendency to interact with the Lewis basic polar pore surfaces of the dehydrated framework probably. It is evident that compound 3 exhibited a type III profile of CO2 adsorption () at 195 K and 1 bar pressure with a maximum uptake of 39 cc/g, whereas compound 2 showed only a negligible amount of adsorption for CO2 (i.e., 8 cc/g) ().

elements.content: In this context, it is important to mention that the dehydrated frameworks of 1–3 exhibited lower amounts of N2 and CO2 uptake with respect to water vapor uptake. This indicates the dehydrated frameworks do not possess adequate spaces between the layers to distribute the N2 and CO2 gas molecules having kinetic diameter (N2, 3.6 Å; CO2, 3.3 Å) greater than water molecules having a smaller size (kinetic diameter, 2.6 Å). In addition, due to strong hydrogen bonding interactions, water molecules are adsorbed to a greater extent. Besides water, to examine the effect of the interaction between the polar solvent and the polar framework, other solvent (EtOH) sorption measurements were conducted at 298 K and 1 bar pressure (Figures S15–S17). The EtOH sorption values are 70, 5.6, 7.8 cc/g at 298 K for the compounds 1–3, respectively. As expected, only a small amount of EtOH adsorption was observed because of the less polar nature and larger size of an EtOH molecule compared to those of a water molecule.

elements.content: The proton conduction properties of the compounds 1–3 were investigated by alternating current (AC) impedance spectroscopy, using pelletized powder samples of 1–3 in the temperature range of 15–65 °C. The conductivities were measured under the variation of both the temperature and relative humidity (% RH), and the Nyquist plots of the impedance spectra of the compounds 1–3 were depicted in , Figures S18 and S19. The Nyquist plots indicated the temperature dependent conductivities for all the compounds at 95% RH. The conductivities for each sample increase with increasing temperature and reached to a maximum value of 3.7 × 10–5, 4.6 × 10–7, and 3.9 × 10–6 S cm–1 for compounds 1–3, respectively, at 65 °C and 95% RH.
elements.clean_text:
Proton Conductivity Studies

The proton conduction properties of the compounds 1-3 were investigated by alternating current (AC) impedance spectroscopy, using pelletized powder samples of 1-3 in the temperature range of 15-65 °C. The conductivities were measured under the variation of both the temperature and relative humidity (% RH), and the Nyquist plots of the impedance spectra of the compounds 1-3 were depicted in  , Figures S18 and S19. The Nyquist plots indicated the temperature dependent conductivities for all the compounds at 95% RH. The conductivities for each sample increase with increasing temperature and reached to a maximum value of 3.7 × 10-5, 4.6 × 10-7, and 3.9 × 10-6 S cm-1 for compounds 1-3, respectively, at 65 °C and 95% RH.

elements.content: This above-mentioned order of proton conductivity for the aforesaid compounds can be explained from various facts. It is obvious that proton conductivity highly depends on relative humidity, and if polar solvent (e.g., water) molecules are present in the interlayer spaces of the synthesized frameworks, proton conductivity sharply increases due to extensive hydrogen bonding in the framework. In our case, the compound 1 showed the highest conduction that can be better explained in terms of its structural dynamism. From VT-PXRD data (Figure S10), it is clear that compound 1 undergoes in a rapid phase transformation. At first, the transformation occurs at ∼50 °C and after that we also observed a phase change at ∼65 °C (the temperature at which proton conduction was studied). It is also worth noting that the structure of 1 activated at 65 °C reverts back to the original structure in the presence of water vapor. Thus, when the proton conductivity had been measured varying the relative humidity, in case of 1 a nonlinear pattern has been found unlike the other two compounds. This also indicated the transformation of the structure in a proton conductive favorable manner. However, this change may have facilitated some reorganization in the structure so that the proton carrier centers reorients themselves in such a manner to give a better impact to the proton conductivity value of the compound. Therefore, we expected this phase transformation phenomenon in compound 1 can be crucially responsible for showing the highest value of proton conductivity than the others where no structural dynamism has been observed. Besides, the presence of protonated free 4,4′-bispyridylethane (bpeH2) ligand inside the framework of 1 contributes in hydrogen bonding to make a better proton conductive channel for compound 1. This factor additively affects the proton conduction value of compound 1 while the other two compounds contain only coordinated N-donor ligands. Between compounds 2 and 3, compound 3 gives a slightly higher value than 2, and this might be due to possessing a higher water uptake capacity at P/P o = ∼0.9, which is a key factor for controlling humidity dependent proton conductivity and/or for accommodating flexible btp ligand in 3 compared to bte ligand in 2.

elements.content: The variation of O···O distances between the oxygen atom of lattice/coordinated water molecules and the oxygen atom of different carboxylic/sulfonic acid groups play an extensive role for making the intermolecular hydrogen bonding network (Figures S4–S6 and Tables S2, S4, and S5). The bond lengths varies from 2.7349 to 2.870(3) for compound 1, whereas for compound 2 and 3 it varies from 2.604(7) to 3.374(9) and 2.681(4) to 3.216(3), respectively (Tables S2, S4, and S5). It is worth mentioning that the variation of O···O distances are very much significant for extensive conjugation of a proton throughout the framework. So from the intermolecular H-bonded data (Tables S2, S4, and S5), it is quite obvious that in compound 1 the proton can move easily from one oxygen center to others because of the shortest O···O distance, but in case of 2 and 3 the O···O distances are larger compared to 1. These O···O distances data quite supports the proton conductivity values of the three compounds in the order of 1 > 3 > 2. In the heating cycle of compounds 1–3, the least-squares fit of the Arrhenius plots also exhibited the estimated activation energy values (E a) of 0.37, 0.48, and 0.30 eV, respectively, signifying the Grotthuss mechanism of proton conduction for all the cases ().

elements.content: We have synthesized three multifunctional sulfonic group functionalized mixed ligand coordination polymers (CPs), where the pore walls are decorated by sulfonated or sulfonic acid group. These functionalized frameworks exhibit high proton conductivity as well as interesting gas and solvent sorption behaviors. All the three compounds possess 2D sheet structures containing lattice water filled 1D channel decorated by sulfonate and carboxylate groups, which help to produce such significant and attractive proton conductivity values through the extended intermolecular hydrogen bonding network composed of the electron rich moiety of the carboxylic, sulfonic acids, and N-donor ligands present in the three frameworks. Here, the compound 1 shows highest proton conductivity because of its structural dynamicity started at the temperature ∼50 °C, which is confirmed by the variable-temperature PXRD analysis. In all the cases, the proton conductivity values are dependent on the temperature and relative humidity factor (% RH). The role of water molecules in these frameworks are thoroughly investigated, and it is clearly related with high-water adsorption uptake values from one side and at the other side it is solely responsible to result high proton conductivity value at higher relative humidity. Selective carbon dioxide adsorption over nitrogen have been observed in the case of compounds 1 and 3, which can make these CPs useful for selective CO2 capture from industrial flue gas. Finally, this work opens a new pathway toward multifunctional mixed ligand CPs synthesis, where the CPs can be used as alternative energy sources and the industrial flue gas adsorbent at the same time. Therefore, this work might be a useful probe to find out the syntheses of some environment friendly multifunctional inorganic–organic hybrid materials showing their two extremely valuable and effective properties in the near future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have synthesized three multifunctional sulfonic group functionalized mixed ligand coordination polymers (CPs), where the pore walls are decorated by sulfonated or sulfonic acid group. These functionalized frameworks exhibit high proton conductivity as well as interesting gas and solvent sorption behaviors. All the three compounds possess 2D sheet structures containing lattice water filled 1D channel decorated by sulfonate and carboxylate groups, which help to produce such significant and attractive proton conductivity values through the extended intermolecular hydrogen bonding network composed of the electron rich moiety of the carboxylic, sulfonic acids, and N-donor ligands present in the three frameworks. Here, the compound 1 shows highest proton conductivity because of its structural dynamicity started at the temperature ~50 °C, which is confirmed by the variable-temperature PXRD analysis. In all the cases, the proton conductivity values are dependent on the temperature and relative humidity factor (% RH). The role of water molecules in these frameworks are thoroughly investigated, and it is clearly related with high-water adsorption uptake values from one side and at the other side it is solely responsible to result high proton conductivity value at higher relative humidity. Selective carbon dioxide adsorption over nitrogen have been observed in the case of compounds 1 and 3, which can make these CPs useful for selective CO2 capture from industrial flue gas. Finally, this work opens a new pathway toward multifunctional mixed ligand CPs synthesis, where the CPs can be used as alternative energy sources and the industrial flue gas adsorbent at the same time. Therefore, this work might be a useful probe to find out the syntheses of some environment friendly multifunctional inorganic-organic hybrid materials showing their two extremely valuable and effective properties in the near future.

cln_elements.content:
The aqueous solution (20 mL) of trisodium-5-sulfoisophthalate (Na3SIP) (1 mmol, 0.312 g) and the methanolic solution (20 mL) of 4,4′-bispyridylethane (bpe) (1 mmol, 0.184 g) were mixed and stirred for 1 h to make the homogeneous mixture. In an another beaker, Cd­(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol, 0.308 g) was dissolved in 20 mL of water. Then, in a glass tube, 6 mL of above-mentioned mixed-ligand solution was slowly and carefully layered on 3 mL of the Cd­(II) solution. A volume of 5 mL of buffer solution (1:1 of H2O and MeOH) was used between the two above-mentioned solutions to perform a slow reaction. Then after sealing the mouth of the tube, it was kept at room temperature uninterruptedly. White block shaped single crystals were obtained after 14 days, and they were quite suitable for further characterization. The crystals were washed with a 1:1 methanol–water mixture after separation and dried under air (yield 75% based on metal salt used). Anal. Calcd for C20H26N2O12SCd (%): C, 38.08; H, 4.15; N, 4.44. Found: C, 38.12; H, 4.11; N, 4.41. IR spectra (in cm–1): ν­(CC), 1613–1433; ν­(SO), 1116(s); ν­(C–O), 1207; ν­(O–H, H2O), 3466; and ν­(C–H, Ar), 3062.

{[Cd<sub>1.5</sub>(bte)­(5-sip)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·3H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

Compound 2 was synthesized following the same procedure of 1 with the use of 1,2-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­ethane (bte) (1 mmol, 0.164 g) in place of 4,4′-bispyridylethane (bpe) (1 mmol, 0.184 g). White block shaped single crystals which are appropriate for structural characterization were obtained after 15 days. The crystals were washed with a 1:1 methanol–water mixture after separation (yield 50%). Anal. Calcd for C28H46N12O26S2Cd3(%): C, 24.58; H, 3.39; N, 12.29. Found: C, 24.61; H, 3.35; N, 12.32. IR spectra (in cm–1): ν­(CC), 1617–1444; ν­(SO), 1127(s); ν­(C–O), 1207; ν­(O–H, H2O), 3494; and ν­(C–H, Ar), 3111.

{[Cd<sub>1.5</sub>(btp)­(5-sip)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Compound 3 was synthesized here not following the hydrothermal method but following the similar procedure as that of 1 with the use of 1,3-bis­(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)­propane (btp) (1 mmol, 0.178 g) in place of 4,4′-bispyridylethane (bpe) (1 mmol, 0.184 g). In this case, white linear shaped single crystals also appeared after 10 days which were separated for further characterization. Using a 1:1 aqueous-methanolic solution, the crystals were washed and were dried (yield 75%). Anal. Calcd for C30H46N12O24S2Cd3 (%): C, 26.49; H, 3.41; N, 12.36. Found: C, 26.47; H, 3.44; N, 12.32. IR spectra (in cm–1): ν­(CC), 1605–1439; ν­(SO), 1125(s); ν­(C–O), 1202; and ν­(O–H, H2O), 3447.

cln_elements.content:
To show the stability of the frameworks with heating, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1–3 was performed in the temperature range of 30–600 °C at the heating rate of 10 °C min–1 (Figure S14). Compound 1 showed a weight loss of 14.34% at 127 °C (calcd 14.28%) due to the loss of one coordinated and four lattice water molecules (Figure S14) per asymmetric unit. The framework was stable up to 270 °C without obvious decomposition. Compound 2 showed a weight loss of 16.14% at 126 °C (calcd 15.78%) due to the loss of three coordinated and three lattice water molecules (Figure S14) per asymmetric unit. The framework was stable up to 309 °C without obvious decomposition. Finally, compound 3 lost a weight of 13.44% at 147 °C (calcd 13.23%) due to the removal of three coordinated and two lattice water molecules per asymmetric unit, and the dehydrated framework was steady up to 310 °C. With further heating, the dehydrated frameworks of 1–3 were disintegrated into unidentified products.

Sorption Studies

The relationship between the adsorbed amount of water and the relative humidity (% RH) is very relevant to this study because the proton conduction is highly dependent on the relative humidity factor. Therefore, the water vapor sorption isotherms for all the compounds have been studied at 298 K ( and Figure S15–S17). The water sorption phenomena for the compounds interestingly display three-step water uptake profiles and the maximum uptake at P/P o = ∼0.9 reaches up to 255, 198, and 266 cc/g for 1–3, respectively. The three-step water uptake was initiated at low humidity with a small uptake, and then two-step pore-filling uptake was observed at ∼9–27% RH. The pore-filling steps were observed at low RH, i.e., 9, 27 and 12% RH, respectively, for compounds 1–3, which indicates the hydrophilic nature of all the samples. It is quite certain from the large hysteresis between adsorption–desorption isotherms that a solvent-filled hydrophilic channel suitable for proton conduction is present in all three structures (). Obviously, the proton conductivity gradually increased according to increment of RH and reached to the maximum value at 95% RH (), which can be explained by the formation of intermolecular H-bonded networks at higher RH.

Thermogravimetric Analysis (TGA)

To show the stability of the frameworks with heating, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds 1-3 was performed in the temperature range of 30-600 °C at the heating rate of 10 °C min-1 (Figure S14). Compound 1 showed a weight loss of 14.34% at 127 °C (calcd 14.28%) due to the loss of one coordinated and four lattice water molecules (Figure S14) per asymmetric unit. The framework was stable up to 270 °C without obvious decomposition. Compound 2 showed a weight loss of 16.14% at 126 °C (calcd 15.78%) due to the loss of three coordinated and three lattice water molecules (Figure S14) per asymmetric unit. The framework was stable up to 309 °C without obvious decomposition. Finally, compound 3 lost a weight of 13.44% at 147 °C (calcd 13.23%) due to the removal of three coordinated and two lattice water molecules per asymmetric unit, and the dehydrated framework was steady up to 310 °C. With further heating, the dehydrated frameworks of 1-3 were disintegrated into unidentified products.

Sorption Studies

The relationship between the adsorbed amount of water and the relative humidity (% RH) is very relevant to this study because the proton conduction is highly dependent on the relative humidity factor. Therefore, the water vapor sorption isotherms for all the compounds have been studied at 298 K ( and Figure S15-S17). The water sorption phenomena for the compounds interestingly display three-step water uptake profiles and the maximum uptake at P/P o = ~0.9 reaches up to 255, 198, and 266 cc/g for 1-3, respectively. The three-step water uptake was initiated at low humidity with a small uptake, and then two-step pore-filling uptake was observed at ~9-27% RH. The pore-filling steps were observed at low RH, i.e., 9, 27 and 12% RH, respectively, for compounds 1-3, which indicates the hydrophilic nature of all the samples. It is quite certain from the large hysteresis between adsorption-desorption isotherms that a solvent-filled hydrophilic channel suitable for proton conduction is present in all three structures (). Obviously, the proton conductivity gradually increased according to increment of RH and reached to the maximum value at 95% RH (), which can be explained by the formation of intermolecular H-bonded networks at higher RH.

metadata.title:
Proton Conductivity and Sorption Study in Three Sulfonic
Group Functionalized Mixed Ligand Coordination Polymers and the Impact
of Structural Dynamicity on Their Property
